I read this article about HTTP requests throughput using python3 and aiohttp library. The author attempts to write an async http client to generate the max. number of requests. I think that this type of articles shows us how NOT to write a benchmarking article :D
 
Although the HTTP request is realistic (requesting a file from disk; not just an echo) and the introduction is catchy, the author failed to benchmark the library very well. First, the article didn't mention benchmark setup: client & server specifications (CPU/memory/network interface etc...). Second, the title is actually misleading: the author failed to write 1M requests per what time unit! Third, the author is adding non realistic delay values between 0-1 seconds; these delays usually follow a distribution and not uniformly distributed as the author used. Fourth, it's clearly that the author didn't do his homework by reading some benchmarking articles/software (it's obvious from the questions he asks in the end).

More importantly, and from the technical viewpoint, this article actually shows that python sucks :D (I used python daily btw). Generating 1M requests in 52 minutes means that the async client can generate ~320 req/sec which is really a small number (the CPUs are fully utilized as the author mentioned). To put this number in perspective, the old "ab" can simply generate 1K req/sec. JMeter can generate 30K req/sec, and "wrk" can generate 750K req/sec!

I think that such articles shed the light on how we should benchmark HTTP request generating tools: workload and delay specifications, minimum CPU/memory requirements, etc..

What do you think?

Aside from the journalistic social media hype, bash on windows explained by technical guys. And it is actually impressive.
To sum up:
- This is a kernel emulator, it emulates kernel APIs for Linux programs.
- it handles File Modes and permissions and inserts them in NTFS extended attributes.
- Currently IPv6 might have some issues. if you have IPv4 it should work fine.
- You can run Ruby or Python and most of the GNU/Linux tools.
- Currently the Linux process is separate from the Win32 world, it runs in its own session (a windows term that is somewhat similar to a container), so /bin/ps will not show Windows processes running on Windows. (Confirm?)
- In the future they plan to span multiple Linux instances in multiple sessions, so each bash can be its own container (this might mean native docker support?)
- Difference from Cygwin and Msys, these are compiled ports to Win32 processes, while now you can run actual linux compiled code.
- Difference from the discontinued SFU that exists in Windows Server (Windows Subsystem [or Services] for Unix).
The difference is that SFU was emulating user mode calls to Win32 equivalents which is a much larger number of API than the Kernel mode.
- Not all the Kernel syscalls are implemented yet.
- Linux apps run in a pico-process (search DrawBridge), so a linux app cannot call a win32 user-mode APIs (also win32 apps cannot invoke linux syscalls),
